Sir can u also explain the algorithms of routing

All end nodes in a LAN of IP say 10.0.0.0 will have IP addresses ranging from 10.0.0.1 to 10.0.0.254. The IP addresses x.x.x.0 and x.x.x.255 are usually reserved in a LAN. Finally, I think all nodes in a LAN use the same subnet mask

I don't think it uses router's ip address as dest. ip address, but an ip address that is an actual dest. ip address. Router will catch every packet that it gets and if it sees that packet's source ip address belong to it's own local ip addresses(beginning with 10.0.0.0 in this case) then it'll know that it needs to take that packet and send it somewhere else(destination ip address that is contained in packet itself).
